descript.abstract:
Frost-free Period (Polygon) is a polygon theme representing areas of similar duration of frost free periods.
Frost-free period is the period when minimum air temperatures near the ground are above zero degrees Celsius so frost does not occur. The duration of the annual frost-free period is one of the principal climatic characteristics that affects the development of biota, human life, and economic activity.

descript.supplinf:
Frost-free Period -- Worldwide distribution pattern The frost-free period decreases toward the poles and, to a lesser extent, from the continental margins toward the interior. Frost-free period is classified into four zones with different frost regimes, as follows: 1. Tropical zone -- no frosts 2. Subtropical zone -- frosts in winter do not occur every year 3. Temperate zone -- periods of spring and autumn frosts are divided by a warm summer and cold winter 4. Cold zone -- frosts are possible during the summer
Frosts do not occur in the plains of the tropical belt and on the coasts up to 30 to 35 degrees latitude in both the northern and southern hemispheres. In some years frosts can occur in the desert highlands of Africa, Mexico, Australia, and Brazil up to nearly 10 degrees latitude. In high mountains, frost periods occur at all latitudes. The frost-free period in the temperate belts decreases from 10 to 11 months at the boundary of the tropical belt to two to two-and-a-half months at the polar circles. The period decreases about two months per 10 degrees of latitude. Mountains are azonal factors. There are no practically frost-free periods in the far north.

procstep.procdesc: The maps were compiled using the data of about 9,000 meteorological stations. Frost-free period is defined as the difference between the last spring and the first autumn air temperatures below zero degrees Celsius. Various geographical factors were taken into account when the station data were interpolated, including heat exchange with ground, atmospheric circulation, the influence of ocean currents, continental climate features, and altitude. We also considered the fact that the vertical gradient of minimum temperature is less than the gradient of mean temperature because of inversion. The vertical gradient of minimum temperature is 0.2 to 0.4 degree per 100 meters. In regions with scarce direct observations (Africa, South America, and Central Asia), indirect methods were used to estimate minimum temperatures using mean temperatures, cloudiness, and other parameters. Isolines were laid out for plains and slopes. They provide general macroclimatic characteristics.
Datasets for each continent were converted from ESRI coverage to the ESRI shapefile format using the 'copy features' tool and merged into one layer using the 'merge' tool.
